summary: This document is a chain of emails between attorneys Mariann Wang and Gloria Allred, and an Assistant U.S. Attorney, discussing the scheduling of interviews for multiple clients who are potential victims of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails contain summaries of the clients' allegations, including timeframes, locations, and interactions with Epstein, Maxwell, and others, including Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Mariann Wang
persons.context: Attorney from Cuti Hecker Wang LLP corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's office and Gloria Allred to schedule victim interviews and request information about case evidence, specifically photographs.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: High-profile attorney from Allred, Maroko & Goldberg, co-counsel with Mariann Wang, involved in coordinating victim interviews with the U.S. Attorney's office.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, the primary point of contact for the attorneys regarding victim interviews and evidence requests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the case; the emails reference multiple clients alleging abuse by him across various locations and timeframes.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Frequently mentioned in the client summaries; alleged to have interacted with victims, left voicemails, and been involved in the abuse.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned in one client's allegation as being present during a final interaction with Epstein in 2010 at a townhouse.

persons.name: Diane Aldrich
persons.context: Executive Assistant to Gloria Allred, who sent a Zoom conference link for a scheduled call.

connections.description: Co-counsels working together to represent multiple clients who are potential victims in the Epstein case.
Attorney corresponding with a federal prosecutor to schedule victim interviews and request case information.
Attorney corresponding with a federal prosecutor to arrange a call regarding potential victims.
Client allegations describe Maxwell interacting with victims and being involved in incidents related to Epstein.
One client alleges an interaction with Prince Andrew occurred during a final meeting with Epstein in 2010.
Diane Aldrich is identified as the Executive Assistant to Gloria Allred.

events.title: Scheduled Zoom Conference
events.description: A Zoom call was scheduled between attorneys Mariann Wang, Gloria Allred, and AUSA Maurene to discuss potential victims prior to scheduling interviews.

events.title: Requested Client Interview Date
events.description: Mariann Wang inquired about the availability of the U.S. Attorney's team to interview clients on this date.

events.title: Alleged Incident (Client AR)
events.description: A client (AR) alleges one incident of abuse in New York in 2002.

events.title: Alleged Multiple Incidents (Client JRC)
events.description: A client (JRC) alleges multiple incidents in New York between fall 2003 and late 2004, with some interactions involving Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Alleged Final Interaction with Prince Andrew
events.description: A client (AR) alleges a final interaction with Epstein in 2010 that included an interaction with Prince Andrew at a townhouse.

events.title: Alleged Multiple Incidents (Client DM)
events.description: A client (DM) alleges multiple incidents in Paris and Florida between August and November 2017, interacting with others working for Epstein.

keyFacts: Attorneys Mariann Wang and Gloria Allred were coordinating with the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) to schedule interviews for at least six distinct clients making allegations against Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.
The client allegations span from approximately 2000 to 2017 and involve incidents in multiple locations including New York, Florida, Paris, California, and Washington, D.C.
One specific allegation mentions Prince Andrew being present during a client's final interaction with Epstein in 2010 at a townhouse.
The attorneys were seeking clarification from prosecutors about the 'scope' of photographs related to the case before informing their clients, indicating the existence of photographic evidence.
The correspondence reveals the logistical and sensitive process of managing victim communications and interviews between civil attorneys and federal prosecutors.
